column2: 1. When a hazard is seen ahead, reaction distance:
column4: is the sum of perception distance and braking distance.
column6: is how far a vehicle will continue to travel, in ideal conditions, before the driver hits the brakes.
column8: equals total stopping distance minus perception distance.

column2: 2. If you remain in the back blind spot of a large vehicle:
column6: the large vehicle will take much longer to stop.
column8: you increase the chance of a crash.

column2: 3. What type of pavement marking shows you which lane you must use for a turn?
4. This road sign warns drivers that:
column4: the road surface ahead changes to a low-type surface or earth road.
column6: vehicles must leave the pavement immediately.
column8: the dirt on the side of the road is soft.

column2: 5. ___________ are green with white letters and symbols.
6. Drivers may pass another vehicle if the line dividing two lanes is a ________ line.

column6: Bicycles have the same rights as other vehicles
column8: Bicycles cross or ride beside traffic
column10: Yield to motorcyles, but not to bicycles

column2: 8. When approaching a highway-rail intersection, the first sign drivers see is usually:
column4: an RXR round sign on a yellow background.

column2: 10. At a light rail intersection, you should always:
column4: share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.
column6: look both ways before crossing the tracks.
column8: be alert and obey all traffic signals.

column6: a dip in the road. Drivers should be ready to stop if the dip is filled with water.
column8: a bridge ahead, wide enough to accommodate two lanes of traffic, but with very little clearance.

column2: 13. If another car has stopped in an adjacent lane in the same direction of travel, you should:
column4: be careful in case the other vehicle has stopped for a pedestrian.
column6: speed up and pass the vehicle on the right.
column8: pass the car on the left.
column10: tap your horn to let the other driver know you are passing.

column4: enhances your ability to see clearly.
column6: makes you less aware of what is happening to your driving abilities.
column10: makes it easier to make correct decisions.

column2: 17. At intersections marked with stop lines, drivers must:
column8: enter the intersection and then stop.
column10: slow down and enter the intersection.

column2: 18. What happens if two vehicles reach at the same time an intersection with four-way stop signs?
column4: The first vehicle to reach the intersection must yield.
column6: The driver on the right yields to the driver on the left.
column8: The driver on the left yields to the driver on the right.
when combined with an octagonal shape, tell drivers they must come to a complete stop at the marked stop line.
Trucks have the right of way

column2: 23. To reduce their chances of colliding with an animal, drivers should:
column4: Slow down when approaching animals that are standing near the road.
column6: scan the sides of the road to watch for the reflection of vehicle headlights in the eyes of animals.
column8: look well down the road and far off to each side.

column2: 24. When driving in fog, drivers should:
column4: use low beam headlights to better illuminate the road ahead.

column10: the left part of the lane nearest to the centerline of the roadway.
